conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I am Student_C and I’m formally applying. School_C is my first-choice school, and I would enthusiastically accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_C, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked behind Student_A and Student_B. To maximize my chance of matching with my first choice before higher-priority students fill the single seat, I should apply immediately to School_C rather than spend a round talking.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. After reviewing priorities for this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_C and wish you the best in the remainder of the process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is applying and ranks School_C as first choice, which increases acceptance likelihood. However, on School_C's true priority list Student_C is ranked 3rd (behind Student_A and Student_B). Since quota is 1 and it is only round 1, accepting now could block a higher-priority match if Student_A or Student_B later apply (both have School_C as 3rd and 2nd choice respectively, so they may plausibly apply in later rounds if not accepted by their higher choices). With no deadline pressure and the ability to wait for higher-priority applicants, it is optimal to reject Student_C now to preserve the seat for potential higher-priority students.

conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions Committee—I'm Student_D. School_D is my first-choice school, and I’m very eager to enroll if admitted. I value your academic environment and would commit to attending if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), meaning I’m relatively lower priority everywhere; delaying could let higher-priority students take the single seat. Applying to my first choice now maximizes my chance to secure it before capacities fill.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We appreciate your commitment and interest in our academic environment. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D applied and is currently the only applicant in my inbox. My true priority list ranks Student_D 4th (behind A, B, C). However, accepting now would fill my only quota and foreclose the chance to match with a higher-priority student if they later apply. Given the market info: Student_A ranks School_D 4th; Student_B ranks School_D last; Student_C ranks School_D 4th; Student_E ranks School_D last; Student_D ranks School_D 1st. This makes it unlikely that higher-priority students (A/B/C) will apply to me early or at all, while Student_D is the most committed and most likely to match with me. To secure a match rather than risk ending unmatched, accepting Student_D in round 1 is a strong move.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—I'm Student_E. School_E is my first choice, and I’m very excited about the chance to join your community. I would like to formally apply for your available seat and will accept immediately if offered.

conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_E is your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to our available seat. Welcome to School_E! [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list ranks Student_E last. Although Student_E is applying now and would accept immediately, I should consider whether higher-priority students (A-D) might apply later. Given all schools share the same priority ordering (A > B > C > D > E) and each student’s first choice is their same-letter school, it is unlikely that Students A-D will apply to School_E in early rounds; they will pursue their top choices first. However, rejections or competition could redirect them. With only one seat, accepting Student_E now guarantees filling the seat but risks missing a higher-priority student later. Still, since Student_E has School_E as first choice and is applying immediately, and there is no evidence of imminent higher-priority applicants in this round’s inbox, accepting is reasonable to secure a match rather than risk ending unmatched.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you for considering my earlier application. I’m writing again to reaffirm that School_C remains my first choice, and if admitted I will accept immediately.

I believe I’m a strong fit for School_C’s academic environment and would be excited to contribute to the community. If there is still an available seat this round, I would be grateful for your reconsideration.

I was rejected last round likely due to higher-priority applicants, but since School_C remains unmatched, there may still be an opening if other top-priority students matched elsewhere. I will re-apply with a clear commitment to enroll if accepted, and briefly highlight fit and readiness without being repetitive.

conversation.message:

At this time, we’re not able to offer you admission this round. Our selection must follow our priority order, and we are keeping our remaining seat available as the process continues.

We wish you the very best in the remainder of the matching process.

Although Student_C is eager and ranks us first, higher-priority students (Student_A #1, Student_B #2) may still apply in later rounds. Accepting Student_C now would forfeit the chance to match with A or B. Given we can wait and prefer higher-ranked candidates, we should reject this round and keep the seat open.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you again for your time in prior rounds. I understand you must follow the priority order.

Before I submit another formal application, could you please advise whether your remaining seat is effectively being held for higher-priority candidates (e.g., Students_A or B), or whether there is a realistic possibility you would consider admitting me if I apply again this round? If there is any specific information that would be helpful to provide to support my candidacy within the rules, I would be glad to share it.

Sincerely,
Student_C
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. I have been rejected due to priority order, likely because higher-priority students may still be in play. A [TALK] message can seek clarity on whether the seat is effectively reserved for higher-priority candidates and whether there is any scenario where applying again would be considered, without wasting an [APPLY] if the answer is definitively no.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your thoughtful note and for your continued interest in School_C.

To answer your question directly: yes—at this point we are keeping our remaining seat available in case higher-priority candidates (particularly Student_A or Student_B) apply to School_C. Under our rules, we must follow the priority order and cannot use additional materials or “fit” statements to move an applicant ahead of others.

That said, there is still a realistic path for you: if Student_A and Student_B do not pursue School_C (or match elsewhere), then we would be able to consider you next in line. If School_C remains your first choice, you are welcome to submit another [APPLY] in a future round, and we will evaluate it against who is actively applying at that time while adhering to the priority order.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: We have 1 seat and our true priority is A > B > C > D > E. Student_C is ranked 3rd, so accepting now could block a higher-priority Student_A or Student_B if they later apply. Student_C has applied multiple times and is clearly committed, but commitment does not change our fixed priority order. Since Student_C is only TALKing this round, we should respond with TALK, be transparent that we are still holding the seat for higher-priority candidates, and encourage them to apply again while noting we can only accept if A and B are not seeking our seat when we decide.

conversation.message:

If higher-priority candidates (Student_A or Student_B) do not apply to School_C this round or are no longer available, I would be grateful to be considered next in line for the remaining seat.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for reapplying and for clearly reaffirming that School_C is your first choice.

At this time, we are not able to offer admission this round. We are still keeping our remaining seat available in case higher-priority candidates (Student_A or Student_B) apply to School_C, and we must follow the priority order.

If you remain unmatched in a future round and School_C is still your top choice, you are welcome to submit another [APPLY]. If Student_A and Student_B are no longer in play for School_C at that point, we would be able to consider you next.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: We (School_C) have quota 1 and true priority order A > B > C > D > E. Student_C is applying again and is our #3. There are no other applicants in our inbox this round, so accepting C now would fill our only seat and prevent us from taking A or B if they apply later. Given Student_A ranks School_C 3rd and Student_B ranks School_C 2nd, either could plausibly come to us in later rounds if they fail to secure their top choice. Since our objective is to match as high as possible on our priority list, it is strategically better to keep the seat open for A or B rather than accept C now. Therefore, reject Student_C again while encouraging them to continue applying if still unmatched and if A/B do not materialize.

conversation.thought: Student_C is #3 on our true priority list. We still have quota 1 and no match yet. Higher-priority candidates Student_A (#1) and Student_B (#2) have not applied to us in round 6 (inbox only has Student_C). Given the market, Student_A prefers School_B then School_A, and Student_B prefers School_A then School_C; it is plausible Student_B could come to us later if rejected elsewhere. However, continuing to hold the seat indefinitely risks ending unmatched by round 30. With no higher-priority applicants currently available to accept, accepting Student_C now secures a match with a student who ranks us first, aligning with our priorities better than leaving the seat empty. Under the rules, we cannot later replace an accepted match, so this is a tradeoff; but at round 6 the risk of missing Student_B seems outweighed by the benefit of filling the seat with our #3 who is committed.
